We know that the infectious dose - the amount of viral particles a person is first infected with - can affect the severity of their later illness. In general, the lower the infectious dose, the less likely a person is to become seriously ill or die, and this will be true for not only the initial infection, but any subsequent reinfections as well. Because there are so few identified cases of reinfection, determining whether reinfection carries a greater risk of severe illness, a lesser risk, or no change, requires that researchers know what the infectious dose was each time a patient was infected. It is only once there is epidemiological data from very large numbers of patients that this information could become less pertinent.

There are other questions raised by confirmation that reinfection is possible. For example, does lingering damage to the internal organs from previous severe Covid illness increase the risk of severe illness, long-term complications, &/or death from subsequent reinfection?
